hedline.hl1: A Legal End to a Name Game

abstract.p: New York State Supreme Court Justice Robert J Gigante bars newly opened Monty Plaza Market Cafe from using name Monty; George Chamoun, owner of nearby Monty Q's pizzeria, lauds decision (S)

block.p: There may be dozens of Ray's Pizzerias in New York City, but the State Supreme Court has ruled that there can be only one Monty's Pizzeria on Montague Street.

In a ruling released last week, Judge Robert J. Gigante barred Monty Plaza Market Cafe, which opened last month, from using the name Monty. Monty Q's, a pizzeria a few doors away, had charged that the new restaurant was capitalizing on its name and reputation.
There may be dozens of Ray's Pizzerias in New York City, but the State Supreme Court has ruled that there can be only one Monty's Pizzeria on Montague Street.

In a ruling released last week, Judge Robert J. Gigante barred Monty Plaza Market Cafe, which opened last month, from using the name Monty. Monty Q's, a pizzeria a few doors away, had charged that the new restaurant was capitalizing on its name and reputation.

''We were, as they say, vindicated,'' said George Chamoun, owner of Monty Q's, which for weeks displayed a sign in the window dissociating itself from the other Monty. ''It was misleading the public. It's a neighborhood place; people know us by our name.'' Mr. Chamoun said he removed the sign on Monday after learning of the ruling.
Harjit Dhir, who owns Monty Plaza, said he would appeal.
